Homecare is defined as a service that regularly delivers medicine supplies and associated care directly to a patient's choice of location. It does not include delivery to a Hospital clinic or ward. Homecare services are split between those which are set up by the Pharmaceutical industry for individual products (under a Pharma-Scheme) and those services which are contracted to an NHS specification.

This Homecare Policy will serve to outline and detail the service specifications across all sites within the msb group of hospitals. For the purpose of this policy; these will be referred to ‘The Trust' unless stated otherwise.

The Policy of the Trust is to commission homecare medicine providers to deliver a high quality service that provides value for money with the emphasis on patient choice, ensuring that high quality medicines are supplied in full and on time.

The Trust offers certain patient groups the choice of receiving their medication as a hospital outpatient via the hospital outpatient pharmacy or to have their medication supplied and delivered directly by a third party ‘Homecare provider' to their nominated address. For those patients who choose to use the homecare service, a Trust clinician will prescribe the medication and send a prescription (via pharmacy) to the homecare provider who dispenses the medication and delivers to the nominated address. Some medication regimens mean that homecare is the only viable method of safe supply to the patient. Patients who do not meet the criteria for homecare services necessitate a review of their treatment plan with their clinician, which may require consideration of alternative therapies.

This document describes the process, roles and responsibilities in relation to the provision of Homecare Medicine Services. It has been written in response to the Department of Health's Report “Towards a Vision for the Future” in Nov 2011 and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society's “Handbook for Homecare Services in England” May 2014.

This policy applies to medical, nursing, pharmacy staff and other key staff involved in any aspects of providing homecare medicines to patients. Its requirements will apply to any Trust Clinical Directorates/Divisions, on all sites, that are planning to introduce new services that may involve homecare supply of medicines.
The purpose of this document is to:
Align the Trust's homecare commissioning and procurement activities with the
recommendations outlined in The Royal Pharmaceutical Society 'Professional Standards for Homecare Services'.
Identify management responsibilities in all aspects of the Homecare medicines service at the Trust.
Outline the current arrangements for the provision of the Homecare medicine service to patients.

Provide a consistent approach across the Trust to the safe and timely procurement of medicines and to ensure that relevant legislation and government guidance as set out in the Hackett report and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society ‘Professional Standards for Homecare Services' is adhered to.
Achieve best value for money for all areas of non-pay expenditure whilst continuing to maintain minimal risk and to provide high quality services to patients.
Ensure that the Trust operates within a statutory framework by adopting standing orders and standing financial instructions
Ensure that all the Trust's business transactions are conducted in accordance with European and English law and government policy

Ensure that business is conducted and managed in a way that will deliver greater efficiency in the use of its resources and ensures probity Ensure that the use of a homecare service does not reduce or alter the NHS duty of care to patients. The Trust and the patient's clinical team will continue to retain responsibility for the clinical aspects of the patient's care unless specified in the contract
Key elements of the policy are:
Governance arrangements concerning the introduction of new homecare treatments
Medicines Pathways
Quality assurance of service provision
Informing and involving patients in the Homecare service
Compliance with CQC standards and current regulations
Definitions

table_items.text: The definition of medicine is that used in the Medicines Act 1968 which uses the term ‘medicinal product'. That is, any substance administered for treating, preventing or diagnosing disease, for contraception, for inducing anesthesia or modifying a normal physiological function.
This term is usually applied to those medicines which do not have a marketing authorisation (formerly product license) Please see Policy for Unlicensed Medicines.

The ordering of a supply of a prescription only medicine for a named patient. (In the extended, commonly-used sense – to authorise by means of a prescription the supply of any medicine (not just a prescription-only medicine). This may be in writing or in an approved electronic format.
A registered medical practitioner or non-medical prescriber.
Commercial Medicines Unit. This is the Procurement investment and commercial division of Department of Health.

Over-arching term for the services run by the Department of Pharmacy. This includes the dispensary, ward-based clinical services, technical services (chemotherapy unit / sterile production), procurement of medicines and quality assurance.
A Registered Pharmacist whose name appears on the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC) Professional Register.

The senior pharmacist on site whose responsibility it is to ensure that patient care and the use of medicines is optimised, through collaboration with Trust prescribers and other healthcare professionals within the Trust.
A department within pharmacy responsible for controlling and regulating services, processes and materials used within pharmacy in order to assure their quality and fitness for purpose.
A Registered Pharmacy Technician whose name appears on the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC) Professional Register.
The independent regulator for pharmacists, pharmacy technicians and pharmacy premises in Great Britain

This is a check of a patient's prescription to ensure the safety and clinical appropriateness of all medication prescribed e.g. indications, co-morbidities, doses, interactions, route of administration, formulations, appropriate monitoring. This is in accordance with a specific pharmacy departmental procedure.
A method of sending and receiving orders and invoices electronically.
A service that delivers ongoing medicine supplies and, where necessary, associated care, initiated by the hospital prescriber, directly to the patient's home/nominated address with their consent.
A compilation of medicines that have been approved for supply to patients under the care of the Trust.
The pharmacy computer based stock control and dispensing system.
A contract between the Trust and a supplier / manufacturer (outside a CMU contract) to supply a product at a fixed price for a fixed period.
The government agency which is responsible for ensuring that medicines and medical devices work, and are acceptably safe. The MHRA is an executive agency of the Department of Health.
Service Level Agreement – Part of a service contract where a service is formally defined.

This refers to all acute hospital sites within the msb group of hospitals. At time of publishing these of hospitals run by: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (SUH), Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust (MEHT) and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (BTUH)
The professional membership body for pharmacists in England, Scotland and Wales.

The review, which was conducted by Mark Hackett and launched in December 2011, that examined the UK's clinical homecare market and looked at ways to develop solutions that support NHS Quality, Innovation, Productivity and Prevention ("QIPP") agenda
East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub (EoECPH)
An organisation that assists and advises member Trusts in the East of England with strategic purchasing support, procurement expertise and commercial skills (‘the hub')
A Homecare supply scheme set up by a Pharmaceutical manufacturer allowing access to medicines via a nominated homecare provider at a preferential rate.
Proof of delivery. Electronic or hard copy capture of a delivery recipient's signature.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Roles and Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
The Local Trust Board
Responsible for:

Ensures that all Board decisions reflect effective Homecare management as appropriate. The Trust Board will receive an annual report/action plan from the Director of Pharmacy on all matters of medicines management including Homecare.
Site Clinical Governance Committee (CGC) (or equivalent)
Responsible for:
Ensures that appropriate action is taken and consideration as to whether further strategic review is required in response to Medicines Optimisation and Management reports.
Medicines Optimisation Committee (MOC)/ Medicines Management Committee (MMC)/ Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG) Responsible for:
Ensures the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy.
Oversees the reviewing of drug developments – new medicines, new indications
and for forecasting future medicine requirements.
Considers new medicines / uses for inclusion within the Trust medicines formulary.
Where necessary the MOC/MMC/MOSG will escalate concerns to the Chief Nurse or Chief Medical Officer as appropriate.
Provide exception reporting to the Site Clinical Governance Committee when
scheduled.
Pharmacy Procurement Homecare team
As per individual responsibilities below.
Roles and Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust

With regard to homecare service commissioning, the Trust will maintain overall responsibility for the service through a cascade of delegated accountability for actions, ensuring that within each level there is an appropriate registered pharmacy professional responsible for homecare and that the definitions of responsibility and accountability defined within this policy are clearly understood by all parties.
Director of Pharmacy/ Group Chief Pharmacist
Responsible for:
Overall responsibility for all activities relating to the procurement and supply of Homecare medicines and associated services undertaken by the Trust.

Establishing and maintaining a system for the secure and safe handling of medicines in consultation with the appropriate medical, nursing and allied healthcare professionals (AHPs) and administrative staff. This role may be delegated on each hospital site to the Site Head of Department (Pharmacy).

Registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council, is accountable for their own actions and omissions. All processes involving any medication must be in accordance with Standards of conduct, ethics and performance (GPhC2010).

Ensuring they are competent for all tasks they undertake. This includes relevant training and maintaining registration, and working continuously within accordance of standards of conduct, ethics and performance.
Regional procurement specialist Pharmacist Responsible for:
Co-coordinating the medicines procurement approach on a regional level.
Ensuring a continual dialogue between the Trust and Pharmaceutical manufacturers.
Representing the interests of the Trust Pharmacy purchasing department at a regional and national level.
Undertake relevant training.
Working within current legislation and within the code of conduct of the GPhC.

Registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council, is accountable for their own actions and omissions. All processes involving any medication must be in accordance with Standards of conduct, ethics and performance (GPhC2010).Ensuring they are competent for all tasks they undertake. This includes relevant training and maintaining registration, and working continuously within accordance of standards of conduct, ethics and performance.
Senior Pharmacy Homecare and Purchasing Technician (or equivalent) Responsible for:

Being registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council, and being accountable for their own actions and omissions. All processes involving any medication must be in accordance with Standards of conduct, ethics and performance (GPhC2010).Ensuring they are competent for all tasks they undertake. This includes relevant training and maintaining registration, and working continuously within accordance of standards of conduct, ethics and performance.
Exercising professional judgment using acquired knowledge and skills when purchasing and supplying medicines and services for Homecare supply.
Ensuring that contracts and local price agreements are adhered to and are accessible to Homecare providers.
Acknowledging and reporting homecare medicine supply problems.
Ensuring any contingency plans, where required, is in place under the appropriate advice.

Ensuring that all processes for the provision of Homecare are efficient and cost effective. Actively seeking new ways to improve costs within the Homecare Service. Where appropriate, liaise with Homecare providers and healthcare professionals to initiate new therapies suitable for Homecare.
Ensuring the authorisation of all purchase orders for homecare-related medicines, where applicable.
Ensuring the processing and passing of invoices for payment.
Providing reports and analysis on Homecare activities within Pharmacy.
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents using the Trust Incident Reporting System/Safeguard and escalating relevant issues as outlined within
this policy.
Maintaining Pharmacy computer system (e.g. JAC / Ascribe) drug files; specifically homecare medicines.

Overseeing the communication between the parties within the Homecare process, providing continuous feedback where necessary and managing/investigating outstanding prescriptions or errors. Act as point of contact for Homecare providers and healthcare professionals within the Trust. Act as liaison between healthcare professionals, patients and Homecare providers when necessary.
Ensuring an efficient and timely response for all processes within the Homecare process, ensuring the safe and successful delivery of medicines to patients.
Actively seeking ways to improve the service of Homecare for all parties, Chair service review meetings with Homecare providers and healthcare professionals.

Liaise with Homecare providers, Director of Pharmacy and the EoECPH team to review and amend call-off contracts under the new Homecare Framework agreement for new therapies, and Core service specifications/therapy specific service variations for individual homecare companies. .
Attend quarterly peer group meetings as organized by the regional lead for Homecare at the East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub (EoECPH).
Processes homecare prescriptions following the Trust SOP, using the JAC/Ascribe system and ensuring correct and efficient delivery of prescriptions to the Homecare providers.
Pharmacy Homecare Assistant (or equivalent) Responsible for:
Ensuring they are competent for all tasks they undertake.
Undertake relevant training, working within current legislation and within standards of conduct, ethics and performance (GPhC 2010).
Processes homecare prescriptions following the Trust SOP, using the JAC/Ascribe system and ensuring correct and efficient delivery of prescriptions to the Homecare providers.
Communicates issues to other parties in the Homecare service, liaising with Homecare providers, healthcare professionals within the trust and patients when necessary.
Oversees the timely receipt of repeat prescriptions and investigates outstanding renewals and/or deliveries.
Maintains secure and up-to-date Homecare patient records.
Provides management reports for Homecare activity.
Supporting the Homecare and purchasing technicians as delegated in accordance with personal competency, adhering to the guidance of the Lead Homecare Technician.
Processes invoices following the Trust SOP, updating the patient homecare records and JAC/Ascribe system. Updating purchasing invoicing records and passing original invoices for payment.
Pharmacy Purchasing Clerk Responsible for:
Ensuring they are competent for all tasks they undertake.
Undertake relevant training, working within current legislation and within standards of conduct, ethics and performance (GPhC 2010).

Support the processing of invoices following the Trust SOP, updating the patient homecare records and JAC/Ascribe system. Updating purchasing invoicing records and passing original invoices for payment.
Provides regular reports for invoice discrepancies to the senior pharmacy technician/s and Homecare Providers.
Ensures timely payment of invoices to Homecare suppliers, within the timeframes detailed in the service level agreement.
Supporting the pharmacy purchasing technicians as delegated in accordance with personal competency.
Consultant, Non-Medical Prescriber and Clinical Nurse Specialists Responsible for:
Comply with the laws and legislations of professional registration with the NMC (or equivalent professional regulatory body) and work within the limitations of role.
Exercising professional judgment using acquired knowledge and skills when prescribing and administering medicines.
Exercising professional judgement on the suitability of patients to be treated via the homecare service.
Ensure patient suitability for treatment, including the assurance of funding for patient treatment.
Responsible for ensuring patient consent for Homecare supply, and providing necessary information to ensure full patient understanding.
Prescribe all medicines clearly with appropriate details to enable safe and accurate administration (dose, frequency etc.).
Ensure appropriate monitoring of treatment efficacy and undertake clinical reviews on a regular and medically appropriate basis.
Ensure consistent and affective communication with pharmacy about changes to patient's treatment, circumstances and complaints.
Sign all prescriptions for medicines and make clear as to the identity of the prescriber. The Trust requires a prescriber to print their name and contact/bleep
number on all prescriptions for this purpose.
Understand the indication, usual dose and frequency, monitoring requirements and side effects of all medicines they prescribe.
Responsible for the accurate and timely submission of new and repeat prescriptions to the pharmacy homecare technician upon request from the Homecare provider.
Specialist Clinical Pharmacist with Homecare Responsibilities Responsible for:
Undertaking a clinical and economic risk assessment of any new homecare therapy.
Approves mechanisms for prescribing and medicines management, including ensuring appropriate training is provided to pharmacy staff.
Act as a point of contact for healthcare professionals on the hospital site.
Act as a liaison between healthcare professionals, patients and homecare providers when necessary.
Attend service review meetings with homecare providers and healthcare professionals, when necessary, providing clinical input to support the homecare technician.
Reporting and investigating medication errors and near miss incidents and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Provide training to junior pharmacists on homecare.
To deal with homecare-related queries from patients, clinical teams or homecare providers, when necessary.
Plan and enforce contingency plans for unforeseen circumstances; together with clinical teams, homecare providers, chief pharmacist and funding bodies (where appropriate).
Duties of the External Homecare Provider
To comply with all aspects of the homecare service as outlined in the contract specification or service level agreement, and in line with RPS and GPhC standards.
To successfully dispense and deliver homecare medications to patients.
To ensure all staff are suitably trained and follow local procedures.
Report regularly on KPI data and ensure regular service reviews are carried out.
To deliver medicines safely and sufficiently, adhering to caldicott laws on patient confidentiality.
To follow pharmaceutical guidelines on the safe and secure storage of medicines and patient sensitive medication.
To comply with the Trust expectations on prescription renewal requests and timely prescription processing, maintaining up-to-date records.
General Principles

Homecare services can be divided into low tech, mid tech or high tech. The complexity of services and therefore the associated competencies required to provide the services increase from low to mid to high tech. The most complex service type definition applies to the overall service. For example: an individual service defined as mid tech may include low tech service elements but not vice versa. Elements of complex homecare may be provided alongside low, mid or high tech homecare services to which this standard refers. These services do not attract VAT and therefore represent a significant saving to the Trust particularly in the provision of expensive drugs.
The purchasing of medicines for the Trust will only be undertaken by persons authorised to do so.

The Pharmacy department will only purchase from a specified range of medicine which reflect current use and the Trust's medicines formulary as approved by the Trust's (MOC/MMC/MOSG), which is on BNF Formulary Complete. The Formulary is accessible via the Staff Intranet and Trust website.

All medicines purchased by the Pharmacy department for Homecare supply will be done so using the pharmacy drug management system (e.g. JAC / Ascribe) and will be undertaken in accordance with this policy and the Trust's standing financial instructions. Medicines will be purchased from trusted sources of supply to ensure
their suitability and to minimise the possibility of counterfeit medicines. Trusted
sources are any MHRA approved supplier that has also been approved by
Pharmacy QA.
Safe and secure methods of procurement (e.g. e-commerce) will be utilised to minimise the potential for error during the ordering process.
Categories of homecare service
Low tech homecare service activities include:
Self-administration of oral therapy (excluding oral oncology), subcutaneous injectable therapies or medicinal products for external use only.
Patient training and competency assessment relating to self-administration.
o  Self-administration needing basic aseptic technique and standard ancillaries e.g. prefilled syringes.
Products are licensed medicines or uncomplicated medical devices.
Supply of products with storage conditions of 15-25°C and/or 2 -8°C for storage in the patient's own fridge.
Self-administration of medicines is usually in accordance with the Summary of Product Characteristics, occasional off-label use.
Mid tech homecare service activities include:
Products that are unlicensed medicines.
Therapy that requires significant clinical support or diagnostic testing such as blood level monitoring as part of the homecare service e.g. oral oncology.
Patient training and competency assessment relating to self-administration.
Self-administration needing basic aseptic technique and standard ancillaries e.g. prefilled syringes.
Medications with special storage requirements.
Provision of refrigeration equipment.
Compliance and/or concordance programmes including specified interventions.
High tech homecare service activities include:
Intravenous infusion.
Self-administration needing advanced aseptic technique and / or portable equipment / specialist ancillaries.
Products that are compounded aseptic medicines administration by healthcare professional.
Using Commissioning of Homecare services
Commissioning Homecare Services
7.1.1 Procurement decisions will be directed by clinical practice and the Trust's current medicines formulary, ensuring that all medicine commissioned for homecare supply are appropriate.
7.1.2 Homecare medicine procurement within the Trust is done so as to take advantage of any national, regional or locally negotiated contracts. Where such contracts and
price agreements exist, these will be extended to the Homecare service provider to ensure medicines continue to be sourced in the most cost effective way.

7.1.3 Homecare service procurement will be managed by pharmacy in a transparent and professional way and overseen by the Director of Pharmacy (delegated to the Site Heads of Department, Pharmacy). Quality assured homecare services are procured through robust and appropriate processes as recommended in the RPS ‘professional standards for homecare services'.
Assessment of Homecare Providers
7.2.1 Prior to the routine use of any new homecare providers, the Trust Homecare Team will obtain appropriate service agreement and contract documentation.

7.2.2 The initial assessment of all homecare providers is undertaken by the East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub, a regional service agreement is then published for individual Trust use, and a Trust-specific assessment is carried out by the Trust Homecare Team. It is the responsibility of the EoECPH to assess, report and provide relevant data and service reviews on a regional scale, including monthly KPI's. The continual assessment of Homecare Providers is based on the supplier's ability to adhere to service and contractual agreements, in respect of prescription management, patient support and confidentiality and medication dispense and delivery. Continuing assessments are to be carried out by the EoECPH and individual Trust Homecare Teams.
Internal Trust Approval Systems

7.3.1 Homecare services will be subject to Trust medicine governance procedures set out by Trust Medicines Management Policies, Pharmacy departmental procedures, Homecare procurement processes and will comply with Trust standing financial instructions.

7.3.2 Medicines to be supplied by the homecare route must follow the NICE technology appraisal (TA) guidelines or be approved for supply by the MOC/MMC/MOSG. Any request to supply non-formulary medicines via Homecare are required to undergo formal submission to the MOC/MMC/MOSG for formulary approval.
Service and contract agreements are set out between the EoECPH, the Trust and the Homecare provider as follows.

Each homecare provider negotiates terms with the EoE to develop a Core Service Specification. This is a regional document finalised and made available by the EoE hub to individual Trusts ready to undertake business with the relative homecare provider.

A service variation document is negotiated by the manufacturer of a drug, and is specific to the service provided for that drug by the relative homecare provider. This is used in the case of pharma-funded treatments.
NHS funded treatments, where the Trust negotiates the level of service to be provided by the homecare provider, are outlined in a call-off contract.
A contract that deviates from those awarded on the EoE hub framework will need an SLA between the homecare provider and individual Trust.

For Homecare Services via non-manufacturer funded / NHS funded medications, a call-off contract will be provided by the Homecare Technician and Senior Technician to the Homecare supplier. This details the service specifications of the Trust as outlined in the Homecare Suppliers core service specification. This is to ensure the RPS standards are adhered to as per individual contract; and awarding the Trust with power to terminate a contract should the Homecare supplier fail to meet the expectations detailed. This is reviewed and signed by the Homecare Supplier and sent back to the Trust Homecare team. Homecare team will personalize any documentation and a final sign off is obtained by, or on behalf of, the director of pharmacy and by the homecare provider at the point of initiation of a new service.
These documents define responsibilities in the following areas:
Patient recruitment and referral
Prescription screening and submission
Patient contact
Medicine delivery
Prescription management
Invoicing
Performance measurement
Problem management
Customer duties
Warranties
Disaster recovery
A copy of all signed call-off contracts, along with existing SLA's from before the change in framework, are kept in the site pharmacy purchasing department.
The East of England Collaborative Procurement Hub (the ‘Hub') work with Procurement and Homecare Technicians across the East of England to provide standardisation of Homecare service variations.

An access-code shall be provided to the trust upon request of any new therapy to initiate the relevant documentation between all parties. Upon completion and acknowledgment from the Hub, a template registration form and prescription shall be provided to the trust for use in that clinic.
Each Homecare therapy area will be risk assessed by the Clinical Specialist Pharmacist in that area and by the Pharmacy Homecare Technician, using the Homecare risk assessment forms (Appendix 2).

data.text: Risk assessments will be undertaken to assess suitability of treatments based on the following key requirements:
Route of administration
Can medication be self-administered?
Does the treatment require the patient to undergo regular blood tests?
Does treatment require next day delivery?
Does treatment require regular dose modification?
Is patient training required

Treatments that are scored as high risk e.g. therapies that require significant clinical support or diagnostic testing such as blood level monitoring as part of the homecare service e.g. intravenous oncology will not be considered for supply via the homecare route.

Homecare medicines supply will not be initiated without first assessing a patient's suitability for the service and ensuring the patient has a full understanding of the requirements and limitations of the service.

Patients will have their medicines history and proposed medicines pathway reviewed by their consultant or Nurse specialist to ensure that Homecare services are appropriate and to optimise outcomes from the medicines pathway.
Patients will only be considered suitable if:

The patient's condition is being maintained effectively on the proposed treatment, or there is sufficient clinical evidence to suggest that treatment will be effective when initiated (following NICE TA guidance).
The patient can agree to adherence of self-medicating or appropriate nurse/carer support is in place, and can agree to attend necessary clinic appointments and blood tests.
The patient is of a fixed address within the UK.
Only if these criteria are met will the patient be invited to consent to have their medicines supplied via Homecare.

Patients will be counselled by an appropriate healthcare professional e.g. prescribing clinician or specialist nurse, to ensure they understand their responsibilities for adhering to the medicine pathway and provisions of the homecare service e.g. attending clinic appointments, taking required diagnostic tests, being available to receive deliveries and/or visits as scheduled, following medicines storage instructions, reporting adverse clinical events and agreeing to reasonable requests from the relevant homecare organisation to ensure continuity of their treatment if for any reason the normal service cannot be provided. Patients will be offered access to Trust Homecare materials and information if they require additional information.

Patients will be provided with clear information about how their personal information is to be shared with the appointed Homecare provider and their GP following the replacement of the Data Protection Act by GDPR in May 2018. It is a requirement that patients are provided with a patient charter and information leaflet.
Prescribing
A patient's treatment must be initiated through a formal process. This may be diagnosis and prescribing by a member of the medical staff or any other Trust authorised non-medical prescriber.

Medicines will be prescribed by registered prescribers, according to their professional registration restrictions and competency and will comply with the requirements under the outpatient prescribing section in the Trust's respective policies on the Safe and Secure Handling of Medicines (see page 2).
Medicines should be prescribed following NICE TA guidance or by approval by the MOC/MMC/MOSG, and will undergo patient specific funding checks by the homecare team.

Prescriptions for Homecare supply may be written on either an outpatient prescription, Sexual Health Prescription form or other approved electronic prescription approved for Trust use by MOC/MMC/MOSG and as specified in the relevant homecare Service variation. Homecare suppliers may provide a generic template prescription, or the Trust/s may use a prescription templated to a specific drug. This is agreed upon within individual call-off contracts.
All particulars entered onto the prescription must be written clearly using a suitable indelible black or blue ink pen. Ballpoint pens are recommended over free flowing inks.
In addition to patient name, address, date of birth and NHS number or Trust hospital (unit) number, prescribers must be explicit in requesting:
The drug to be dispensed
The form (i.e. Tablet, injection etc.)
The strength to be dispensed
The quantity to be dispensed
The duration of supply
Prescription screening

All prescriptions written by prescribers for supply via Homecare will be received into pharmacy dispensary, where they will be passed on or made available to the relevant clinical pharmacist responsible for homecare in that therapy area. The relevant pharmacist will undertake a clinical screen of the prescription in line with departmental procedures.
Prescription Management
On-going renewal of prescriptions (prescription management) will be undertaken by prescribers in conjunction with the Homecare provider.
The Homecare supplier will undertake prescription management processes and notify the prescribers and homecare team whenever repeat prescriptions are required.

Prescription management teams within the homecare provider network will issue requests on a repetitive basis starting from 6 weeks before the patients next scheduled delivery, and sufficient notices will be given to ensure the patient is not left without a supply of medication. It is the Homecare provider's responsibility to request prescriptions in a timely manner, and to perform routine stock checks with the patient to ensure sufficient stock is always maintained. At the point of request, the clinic and homecare teams have a 10 working day required time frame to produce and process a prescription and send it to the provider.

The decision to provide a replacement prescription remains the responsibility of the prescriber. Replacement prescriptions can be withheld by the clinical team if the patient is non-compliant with the requirements of the homecare service.

Each new Homecare prescription will have an individual purchase order (PO) generated on the Pharmacy JAC/Ascribe system. The unique PO will be quoted together with the patient's hospital number on any correspondence relating to supply against that prescription.
The following will be sent by post to the Homecare provider, using pre-paid envelopes supplied by each homecare provider:
The original prescription
Patient registration form (if for initial supply)

In the event of urgent supply (where patient has less than 7 days of medication remaining), a copy of each prescription and registration form (if for initial supply) will be sent to the Homecare provider's emergency prescription team. This will be via secure encrypted email, with the original paper copy sent in the post as usual. The authorization of emergency prescription supply and payment for this service is at the discretion of the Trust clinical and homecare teams and will comply with the service and contract agreements.
In the event of an emergency prescription charge to the hospital, each case should be assessed individually and the charge afforded to the relevant area where service fault occurred. For example:
Fault of homecare provider:
Error in delivery.
Lack of communication on behalf of provider.
Lost prescription once received by supplier.
Renewal for prescription not requested by provider within time frame specified in service variation.
Fault of Clinic
Incorrect dose (that cannot be immediately defined by pharmacist screen).
Incorrect frequency (that cannot be immediately defined by pharmacist screen).
Prescriptions not sent to pharmacy within sufficient time frame.
Prescriptions not signed by prescriber.
Prescriptions missing registration forms.
Prescriptions containing wrong patient information (that cannot be immediately defined by pharmacist screen).
Fault of Pharmacy
Delay in pharmacy-only aspects of processing the prescription.
Prescriptions not correctly ordered by pharmacy team.
Prescriptions sent to the wrong provider.
Prescriptions missing pharmacist signature.
Copies of the following documentations will be held within Pharmacy and will only be accessible to authorized pharmacy staff:
Patient registration form (copy).
Funding application and approval letter.
Prescription (copy).
Original Purchase order per prescription.

Proof of delivery per invoice and original purchase orders relating to the supply of Homecare medications will be held securely within Pharmacy and will be accessible only to authorised pharmacy staff.
Completed prescriptions will remain in the pharmacy for a total of 2 years, then archived following the Trust's prescription policy regarding record keeping.
Patient records on the pharmacy JAC/Ascribe computer system will be maintained and updated whenever a delivery of medication is made.

Medication will be recorded as received onto JAC/Ascribe only upon receipt of a POD and the patient's record updated using JAC/Ascribe in accordance with pharmacy dispensing procedures to reflect the homecare providers dispense and supply of medication.
This information will then be updated onto the relevant patient spreadsheet record to maintain an accurate account of all activity.
Homecare supplier invoices will be generated by the Homecare provider upon successful delivery of medication into the patient's chosen delivery address.
Invoices will only be processed by Pharmacy upon receipt of a proof of delivery.
Invoices will be checked for compliance against known contract prices or local price agreements and will only be paid if the values are correct.
Invoice discrepancies (overcharges or undercharges) will be referred back to the Homecare provider for credit and / or re-invoicing.

Invoices will be passed for payment in a timely manner, authorised and submitted to finance for payment within 4 weeks of receipt. Upon receipt of a statement from the homecare provider a member of the homecare team will review the statement for any overdue invoices and these will be investigated and referred back to the homecare provider when necessary.

Patient records kept in pharmacy will be updated accordingly whenever a patients prescription or delivery requirements change. Any changes to patient's prescription requirements or medication (dose, device, frequency) will be communicated immediately by the clinical team to the Homecare provider, and the trust homecare team will be involved in all communication. This to ensure that patient safety issues do not arise as a result of incorrect dispensing by the Homecare provider.

Problems with the supply of medicines as a result of manufacturing difficulties will be continually monitored by the Homecare Provider and a contingency plan discussed and implemented in conjunction with the Homecare and Procurement team to ensure continuity of supply to patients. This may involve moving the supply of medication back to the Trust onsite pharmacy.

Internal Trust face-face training is provided by pharmacy to all staff involved in Homecare. All relevant SOP's must be read and understood. Individuals are to work within the limitations of their qualifications and job specifications.
Monitoring patient outcomes
Patients' outcomes from and their experiences of treatment with homecare services will be documented, monitored and reviewed as detailed below.

The EoE Hub will undertake periodic patient satisfaction surveys in collaboration with the homecare providers. Results of these surveys will be collated by the hub and shared with the homecare providers and trust homecare teams to improve the homecare services and patient experience.

Homecare patients will attend regular clinic reviews with their hospital consultant or specialist nurse to ensure response to their medication, compliance with medicine pathways, unwanted side effects and service complaints are monitored and documented. Patients using the Homecare service will remain under the care and responsibility of the Trust.
Appropriate action, in line with the appropriate Trust policy, will be taken where problems (potential and actual) are identified by either Trust staff or the Homecare provider.
Where complaints are received from patients,this will be dealt with by the Trust.
Incident reports, statements, investigation reports and other associated documentation will be treated as confidential and available to the corporate Trust governance & risk teams as required.

Where the homecare provider identifies a prescribing error or is alerted by a patient to an error or omission with their medicine, the homecare provider will inform the homecare pharmacy technician who will document the incident via the Trust Incident Reporting System.

All Trust staff responsible for the provision of Homecare medicines will document any patient safety, information governance or safeguarding incident and report it to the service commissioner and external agencies, in line with NHS guidance on patient safety alerts.
Monitoring service levels of Homecare Providers

Adherence to agreed service levels will be monitored on a monthly basis through the provision of Key Performance Indicators (KPI's) from each Homecare provider. These are reported to the EoE hub where all relevant data is collated and made available to the trust homecare team. KPI's are set by the EoE and developed by the CMU.

Quarterly service reviews held with Homecare providers and chaired by the pharmacy homecare Technician will address performance of service providers using the KPI's as evidence of adherence to agreed service levels.

Deviation from agreed service levels will be investigated by senior members of the homecare team and remedial action agreed and acted upon through service review meetings between the team and homecare provider.
Implementation of any corrective action will be assessed by senior members of the homecare by the monitoring of subsequent KPI's.

Appendix 4: Homecare service expectation

Upon receipt of any new patient registration form, the Homecare supplier will contact the patient to validate the details on the registration document (name, address & date of birth). This initial contact will also serve to provide the patient with Homecare supplier contact information.
All prescriptions received by the Homecare provider will undergo a screening process by the Homecare supplier prior to dispensing and supply to the patient.
Prescribing errors or prescription details that are unclear will be reported back to the prescribing clinic and homecare technician for clarification and action.

Before dispensing by the Homecare supplier, a pharmacist will review each prescription to ensure they are legally valid and unambiguous. Any doubt as to the prescriber's intentions will be clarified with the pharmacy homecare technician and prescriber before being processed.
The homecare supplier will dispense medication in accordance with the instructions supplied on each prescription and all medicines will be supplied with a patient information leaflet (PIL).
The labeling of dispensed medicines will take into account the diversity of patients accessing Homecare medicines, for example the elderly and the disabled.
Urgent homecare medications, where for whatever reason a patient's medication is required to be delivered within 24 hours, will be prioritised for dispensing and delivery.
Depending on the nature of the treatment, the frequency of delivery of a medication may vary but will reflect the instruction of the Trust prescriber as specified on the prescription.
All patients will be contacted by the homecare supplier prior to dispatch of each medication supply to ensure a mutually agreeable delivery time and to confirm the pre- agreed delivery address.
Delivery will be made by the homecare supplier by means of either a contracted logistics partner or by their own logistics division.
Upon delivery, the patient's details will be checked and signed proof of delivery (POD) obtained.
Any clinical waste generated by the patient as part of their Homecare treatment will be collected by the Homecare supplier and returned to the Homecare supplier for safe destruction.
